review.title: Two New Definitions of Stable Models of Logic Programs with Generalized Quantifiers
review.abstract: We present alternative definitions of the first-order stable model semantics and its extension to incorporate generalized quantifiers by referring to the familiar notion of a reduct instead of referring to the SM operator in the original definitions. Also, we extend the FLP stable model semantics to allow generalized quantifiers by referring to an operator that is similar to the $\sm$ operator. For a reasonable syntactic class of logic programs, we show that the two stable model semantics of generalized quantifiers are interchangeable.

sections.heading: 4 FLP Semantics of Programs with Generalized Quantifiers
sections.text: The FLP stable model semantics [1] is an alternative way to define stable models. It is the basis of HEX programs, an extension of the stable model semantics with higher order and external atoms implemented in the system DLV-HEX. The first generalization of the FLP stable model semantics for programs with aggregates was given using the FLP operator, which is similar to the SM operator. In this section we will show how it can be extended to allow generalized quantifiers.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We have introduced two definitions of a stable model: one is a reformulation of the semantics of the first-order stable model and its extension to allow generalized quantifiers by reference to grounding and reduction, and the other is a reformulation of the semantics of the FLP and its extension to allow generalized quantifiers by referring to a translation into a secondary logic. These new definitions help us to understand the relationship between the semantics of the FLP and the semantics of the first-order stable model and their extensions. For the class of programs in which the two semantics coincide, the DLV-HEX system can be seen as an implementation of the stable model semantics of GQ formulas; a recent extension of the F2LP system [19] to include "complex" atoms as the front-end of DLVHEX to implement the generalized semantics of the FLP.
